fields.title: About Community Profiles
fields.content:
This site is designed to provide Rhode Islanders with easy access to data about their communities and assist them in making sense of this information. We hope to empower the government, businesses, nonprofits, institutes of higher education, and residents to use this information to identify local needs, prioritize investments, and advocate for community change. 

Rhode Island Community Profiles was created and is maintained by The Providence Plan. Funding for the project comes from the Rhode Island Foundation and the Rhode Island Statewide Planning Program.
###Data Sources

Data on this site comes from the US Census Bureau as well as data made accessible through the RI Department of Health, RI Department of Education, and the RI Department of Children, Youth, and Families. We are actively pursuing new data partnerships and will add additional datasets as they become available. If you are a community partner and you are unable to find the data you are looking for, please contact us: jlucht@provplan.org.

###Open Source Development
This site is an open-source project. The code, design, and structure for the site will soon be publically available, free of charge. We look forward to sharing the template we have developed with other organizations across the country that are interested in helping democratize data on behalf of their communities.

###Future Improvements
We are hard at work developing a variety of new features including:

- A “My Shelf” feature that will allow users to save and organize their maps, charts, and graphs.
- A “create your own neighborhood” feature that will allow users to create and save a unique geographic area of interest and display data for that area. 
- Neighborhood-level data for communities with traditionally established neighborhoods (e.g. Providence, Pawtucket, Cranston, Woonsocket, and East Providence).

fields.title: About the Data
fields.content:
#Data Sources
Data on this site comes from the US Census Bureau, the RI Department of Health and eventually the RI Department of Education. Maternal and child risk factor data (teen birth, delayed prenatal care, etc.) comes from the RI Department of Health. Detailed public school student counts and related indicators will come from RI Department of Education.

We are actively pursuing new data partnerships and will add additional datasets as they become available.  

#Background on Census Data
According to law the US Census Bureau is required to collect the short-form census, which is mailed to all households every 10 years and collects basic information such as age, sex, race, and number of households.  The bulk of this information is contained in Census Summary File 1 (SF1) or Short Form. Through the 2000 Census the bureau also collected Summary File 3 (SF3) or Long Form data. In addition to collecting basic demographic information, it asked around 50 additional questions about socio-economic and housing characteristics.  In 2000 it was sent to about one 1 out of 6 households.  

After the 2000 Census, the US Census Bureau discontinued SF3 and replaced it with the American Community Survey (ACS). The ACS is a random survey of the population conducted continuously throughout the year.  A random sample is surveyed each year so multiple years of data are combined to try to account for the true population of all areas.  Many of the questions asked by SF3 are now available on the ACS, but not all. Additionally, due to a smaller sample size, some data are unavailable at finer levels of geography.  

The ACS is available for 3 different time categories that represent different levels of geography: 1‐year (areas above 65k population), 3‐year (areas above 20k population), and 5‐year (tract and block group). The 5‐year ACS estimates are the data that replicate SF3; census tract and (some) block group level data are available, but margins of error are wide and we have chosen only to display tract-level data in the Community Profiles.

The 2006‐2010 5‐year survey data is keyed to the 2010 short-form census results. It is appropriate to compare SF3 and ACS 5‐year data for many but not all variables. See the Margin of Error section below for a description of sampling error for the ACS.

#CHANGES IN GEOGRAPHIES
Census geographies are updated every decade to account for population shifts and growth. State‐wide geography does not change. Municipalities generally should not shift in geography but there are few cases where blocks are attributed to different RI municipalities between 2000 and 2010 (Example: a few Providence blocks were attributed to Johnston).

Census tracts have the most change. They can be added, removed, split, or consolidated (roughly based on a population target of 4,000). Within tracts, block groups and blocks can also be added, removed, split or consolidated. Documentation of all changes is available on the Census TIGER website. http://www.census.gov/geo/www/tiger/

Changes to geographies make comparisons difficult across datasets and years. For SF1 data, ProvPlan created a statewide 2000 block to 2010 tract crosswalk that works in the background to allow users to see 2000 count data as‘2010’ tracts to be able to compare data over time. SF3/ACS was more challenging, particularly for medians and averages that are tricky to impute or interpolate. We overcame this by using 2000 block groups to constitute 2010 tracts where the tract had changed (only five tracts in the State). In the even rarer case where 2000 block groups did not fit within 2010 tract boundaries, we used underlying block values to split the variable proportionally between the two 2010 tracts.

MARGIN OF ERROR 
As indicated above, the American Community Survey is a continuous sampling of population and households throughout the year. The data are sample estimates and are subject to sampling error. Margins of Error are provided for each estimate at each geography level and should always be checked before drawing conclusions. Depending on the level of geography the estimates may have a margin of error too wide to show any meaningful change over time.

To overcome wide margins of error ACS users have a few options. They can sum across table categories to create new groups (ex: age 0‐5 instead of age 0, 1,2,3,4,5 alone), sum up several tracts to create a new geography level (ex: add several tracts together to get a neighborhood), or do a combination of the two.  Users have to create new estimates and new margins of error when summing up categories or across geographies. Documentation of necessary formulas is provided by Census in ACS handbooks. <link to handbooks>
The Community Profiles deals with MOE in several ways. First we recalculate MOE automatically for any of our indicators that require a combination of multiple fields. This is very convenient for the user because our published indicators are based on popular demand and help overcome the fact that the Census is very fine-grained and users inevitably combine fields to get what they want. Secondly we provide margin of error in all of our ACS tabular output. A user can easily see whether the MOE is larger than a change figure. Lastly we provide error bars on our Map & Ranking graphics. Although we do provide interactive mapping without indication of MOE, our hope is that users will get more mileage out of the Map & Ranking because it is a more powerful data display for analysis.

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION
Additional information on Census Data is available here.  http://provplan.org/assets/uploads/fom/CensusResourceSheets.pdf

Census 2010 Block-level Data with Common SF1 Variables is available from our partners at the Rhode Island Geographic Information System here. http://www.edc.uri.edu/rigis/data/data.aspx?ISO=society

fields.title: About ProvPlan
fields.content:
The Providence Plan is an independent 501c3 nonprofit that provides Rhode Islanders and public agencies with data and information to support critical decision making. Our innovative programs improve community well-being and transform lives.

We believe that information – what exists, how it is used, and who uses it – is a fundamental aspect of community revitalization in an age of expanding information technology.

We work to democratize information by transforming data from spreadsheets and complex databases into maps, charts, and interactive tools that empower policymakers and residents to advocate for community change.

Our data warehouse, the largest of its kind in Rhode Island, is compiled from federal, state, and local statistics. By bringing together data from multiple sources, our tools provide a comprehensive snapshot of communities that would otherwise be unavailable.

Over the next several years we look forward to leveraging new technologies that will allow us to present greater amounts of information more quickly - and in increasingly interactive formats. We also remain fundamentally committed to expanding the work of our programs and seeding new initiatives that are consistent with our mission.

__Other data tools and details about ProvPlan programs at ProvPlan.org__
